description: A Home Away From Homelessness is an after-school program that serves homeless and formerly homeless youths in San Francisco.
volunteer: Provide tutoring services, serve as monthly companions, and run creative fundraising projects as needed.

description: Abode Services is working to end homelessness in Santa Clara, Alameda, Santa Cruz and San Mateo counties by securing permanent homes for individuals and families.
volunteer: Serve on committees and their Board of Directors, prepare and serve meals, help sort and store donated items, perform light cleaning and maintenance, and more: www.abodeservices.org/support_us/volunteers.

description: Alameda Point Collaborative is the largest provider of supportive housing for homeless families in Alameda County.
volunteer: Serve as urban farmers and tutors for children.

description: Ambassadors of Hope and Opportunity is a youth-led program that helps homeless teens and young adults ages 18 to 25 with personalized, comprehensive resources and leadership opportunities for up to five years. AHO has 120 Alliance for Youth community partners; housing, jobs, dental, cell phone, laptops, counseling, scholarships for college, eye glasses and more.
volunteer: Book speaking engagements with high school leadership, provide a room in your home for a youth who needs transitional housing, offer professional services pro bono or volunteer at events and fundraisers.

description: Back on My Feet is a national organization with chapters across the country including San Francisco. This organization works to combat homelessness through the power of running, community support and essential employment and housing resources.
volunteer: Run between one and four miles with members or help out at community events. Follow this link for volunteer information, https://sanfrancisco.backonmyfeet.org/node/3491.

description: Bay Area Rescue Mission offers a clean, safe place to sleep as well as a yearlong program to help adults get back into a functional, productive life.
volunteer: One-time and regularly scheduled opportunities, group volunteering, collection drives and internships are available.

description: Berkeley Food & Housing Project provides a comprehensive range of housing, food and support services to help those in need move from homelessness into a safe and affordable home of their own.
volunteer: Afternoon and evening meal service, food prep and facilities maintenance.

description: Beyond Emancipation supports Alameda County’s current and former foster and probation youth to achieve success in housing, education, employment, permanency and wellness.
volunteer: Tutor community college students, lead a part of the culinary training program or participate in career panels.

description: Building Futures helps people affected by homelessness and domestic violence by operating a safe house, emergency shelters, a permanent housing site and offering rental assistance.
volunteer: Work with children served by emergency shelters and domestic violence safe house; donate meals, provide building maintenance; crisis line operations; administrative duties.

description: Building Opportunities for Self Sufficiency provides housing, employment, mental health services and violence prevention solutions.
volunteer: Fundraising/marketing, board membership and consulting, teaching classes to homeless shelter residents, coaching job seekers, and tutoring in the after-school Children's Learning Center.

description: CalFresh is a nutrition-assistance program that helps families and individuals purchase food.
volunteer: Assist city residents in applying for CalFresh benefits and help Food Bank staff connect community members to CalFresh benefits through outreach.

description: Through shelter programs, housing subsidies, eviction prevention services and permanent supportive housing programs, Catholic Charities of San Francisco ensures vulnerable people have homes to provide a foundation to focus on restoring stability and hope.
volunteer: A diverse range of volunteer opportunities, visit www.catholiccharitiessf.org/all-opportunities to learn more.

organization: Catholic Charities of the East Bay
description: Catholic Charities of the East Bay works with youths, children and families to promote self-sufficiency, strengthen families and pursue safety and justice. It is the largest provider of social services throughout the East Bay.
volunteer: A diverse range of volunteer opportunities, visit  www.cceb.org/get-involved/volunteer to learn more.

description: Charlotte Maxwell Clinic is a free public health clinic that provides integrated medical services in Alameda, Contra Costa, Solano, San Francisco, Marin and San Mateo counties via a volunteer network of more than 400 health care practitioners.
volunteer: Licensed acupuncturists, certified massage therapists, guided imagery specialists, Western herbalists, homeopaths, drivers and Spanish or Chinese language interpreters are needed. Volunteers can also offer support in the clinic assisting with fundraising, development or outreach.

description: Children of Shelters offers unique educational opportunities, cultural experiences and enrichment activities.
volunteer: Volunteers needed at shelters and holiday fundraising events.

description: Cityteam provides food, shelter, clothing, training and spiritual transformation. These programs help to address poverty and homelessness in San Jose, San Francisco and Oakland by caring for immediate needs and enabling lasting solutions.
volunteer: Donation pick up driver, help in the kitchen, donation sorting, warehouse help, assist at special events, serve meals and more.

description: Coalition on Homelessness is an advocacy organization that works to protect the human rights of those forced to remain on the streets.
volunteer: Outreach to homeless people, research, policy development, writing for the organization’s newspaper, artwork and poetry, photography.

description: COTS offers comprehensive services in hopes of breaking the cycle of homelessness.
volunteer: Prep and serve meals, interact with children, pack and deliver food boxes, mentor adults, and more

description: Community Action North Bay provides housing, food, clothing, case management, money management and other training.
volunteer: Help with inventory, sorting and bagging food on Tuesday and Wednesday mornings, provide social support to housing clients, and help with clerical and bookkeeping duties

description: Community Education Partnerships provides educational support to children who are experiencing, or have been affected by, homelessness.
volunteer: Weekly one-on-one tutoring and mentoring to PK-12 students.

description: Community Housing Partnership pairs affordable housing with resident and clinical support services, employment preparation, job training, a transitional employment social enterprise, and community organizing/resident engagement to empower community members and create a direct pathway from homelessness to self-sufficiency.
volunteer: A variety of engaging volunteer opportunities are available for both individuals as well as corporate groups – including, but not limited to, policy and program, assisting with fundraising and special events, and teaching resident classes.

description: Compass Family Services has been helping families facing homelessness transition from crisis to economic stability since 1914. They work with nearly 4,000 homeless and at-risk parents and children each year, providing services needed to help families achieve well-being and self-sufficiency and become stably housed.
volunteer: Host a drive or fundraiser, help with administrative duties, organize the office space, serve Sunday dinner to families, fulfill program and classroom wish lists, teach a class or workshop, take photos of events and classes, haul away junk, or scan files

description: Contra Costa Crisis Center operates crisis lines, including specific help for homeless people and families.
volunteer: Crisis line counselor (training is held twice a year for crisis lines and 211 lines), thrift shop volunteer, clinical internships, community projects volunteer.

description: Contra Costa Interfaith Housing provides permanent, affordable housing and support services to families and individuals in Contra Costa County.
volunteer: After-school tutors (one day a week), monthly dinners for clients, people with trucks for hauling, and setting up apartments for clients.

description: Covenant House California is a shelter for homeless youths ages 18 to 24, many of whom have been abandoned by their families or aged out of the foster care system.
volunteer: Tutoring, mentoring, food prep and cooking, administrative tasks, fundraising, facility repair and upkeep.

description: Curry Senior Center provides health and social services to homeless and low-income San Francisco seniors. Services include health care, counseling, housing, meals, and socialization.
volunteer: Volunteers are needed daily to plate and serve food and socialize with the seniors. The breakfast shift, runs from 7am -9am and lunch runs from 10am - 1pm.  Please call or email to volunteer.

description: Davis Street Resource Center provides emergency food, clothing, child care services and medical, dental and counseling services through our Primary Care Clinic, all available to residents of San Leandro, San Lorenzo, Ashland, Cherryland and Castro Valley.
volunteer: Administration and medical volunteers.

description: Delivering Innovation in Supportive Housing provides permanent housing to people suffering serious health issues. DISH is a project of Tides.
volunteer: Fund development, marketing or social media strategy, painting projects, sidewalk gardening, Tenant Appreciation, Party Health and Wellness Fair, DISH Anniversary Bash and other fun projects.

description: Dolores Street Community Services serves the Mission and Castro neighborhoods with a variety of programs, including shelter, housing and immigration services.
volunteer: Nightly volunteers are needed every day from 6:30 to 10 p.m serving food, distributing linens and working bingo nights.

description: Dorothy Day House provides food support, emergency winter shelter and other services.
volunteer: Preparing and serving food.

organization: DrawBridge: An Arts Program for Homeless Children
description: DrawBridge provides art programs for homeless and other underserved children where they live, creating an environment that fosters creativity, joy, self-confidence and hope.
volunteer: Help with weekly art groups, supporting and encouraging the children's creative explorations. A six-month commitment is requested.
address: P.O. Box 2698, San Rafael, San Rafael, CA 94912

description: Community organizing group run by "milennials-plus," serving "deep East Oakland." Works towards racial and economic equality. Works in housing for the homelessness.
volunteer: Prepare lunch and hygine kits and distribute to the homeless and needy.

description: Eden I & R, Inc. is a centralized source of health, housing and human services information in Alameda County and is the operator of 211 Alameda County, the free, 3-digit phone number for 24/7 multilingual assistance with referrals to health, housing and human services. 211 is the countywide call center for the Coordinated Entry System, to assist those living in homelessness.
volunteer: Office administrative work, research, updating database listings and making quality assurance calls to 211 callers.

description: Episcopal Community Services San Francisco operates shelters, Navigation Centers, supportive housing, job training, adult education and senior services.
volunteer: Serve breakfast or dinner at shelters, tutor adult GED students or assist senior citizens. Group volunteer opportunities are also available.

description: Eviction Defense Collaborative provides emergency rental assistance and helps tenants respond to unlawful detainer lawsuits.
volunteer: Under the supervision of a staff attorney, legal volunteers and interns interview and counsel tenants facing eviction and assist in the preparation of necessary paperwork. Volunteers in the Rental Assistance component (RADCo) work under the direct supervision of our Rental Assistance Coordinators. RADCo volunteers interview tenants needing rental assistance and assist the program coordinators with various administrative tasks. Also, the EDC fundraising staff are eager to train a grant writer in exchange for some assistance in the development department.

description: Family Supportive Housing provides temporary shelter and support to families.
volunteer: Sort gift items, help parents pick out gifts for their children, help children pick out gifts for their parents, prepare and serve meals.

description: Farming Hope hires homeless neighbors to perform garden and cooking work, providing part-time transitional employment and on-the-job training. They also share free meals and sell food at a pop up restaurant location near the Civic Center.
volunteer: Assist employees in gardens, kitchens and at community meals.
address: 555 Golden Gate Ave. on Thursday evenings

description: FESCO, a collaboration of more than 24 churches in mid-Alameda County, offers food, supportive services and emergency, transitional and permanent housing.
volunteer: Office administrative work and life-skills instructors.

description: Food Runners collects and delivers more than 15 tons of food a week that would otherwise be thrown away.
volunteer: Sign up to become a food runner, delivering food to those in need throughout San Francisco on a regular or on-call basis.

description: Glide Memorial Church provides food, access to health care, child care, housing, jobs, a safe harbor and unconditional love.
volunteer: Serve meals in the daily free meals program, work with children, get involved in the HIV services center, help the fundraising or finance office, help at Sunday celebrations and assist with special events.

description: Haight Ashbury Food Program serves approximately 150 low-income people and families in the area surrounding the 94117 ZIP code. They provide food from the local food bank and Trader Joe's.
volunteer: Assist with food pantry operations every Saturday, help with small projects.
address: Mailing address: P.O. Box 170202, San Francisco, CA 94117. Location: 1525 Waller St., San Francisco

description: Hamilton Families established San Francisco’s first shelter for families experiencing homelessness. Today they are San Francisco’s leading service provider to homeless families, with an array of highly effective programs at sites in San Francisco and Oakland.
volunteer: Work with children in the digital learning center, and many more opportunities. Please email for the best fit.

description: The Healing WELL is a holistic healing and wellness center in the heart of the Tenderloin neighborhood.  They offer free classes such as yoga, meditation, 12-steps for healing, art, poetry and improv theater.
volunteer: Facilitate wellness groups and classes both on-site and in the community, prepare and serve meals, and offer hospitality.

description: HealthRIGHT 360 provides medical, mental and substance abuse treatment.
volunteer: Seeking volunteers for program support. Contact volunteer coordinator for details.

description: HomeFirst is a leading provider of services, shelter, and housing opportunities to the homeless and those at risk of homelessness in Santa Clara County. They serve more than 4,000 adults, veterans, families, and youth each year at seven locations including the Boccardo Reception Center, which is the county’s largest homeless services center.
volunteer: Individuals can donate their time at one of the local shelters, family sites, or kitchens, or HomeFirst can also help you complete a service project at your site.

description: Homeless Action Center provides free public benefits advocacy to low-income people in Alameda County.
volunteer: Internships for law students.
address: 3126 Shattuck Ave., Berkeley; 1432 Franklin St., Oakland; 2601 San Pablo Ave., Oakland

organization: Homeless Advocacy Project (HAP) of the Justice & Diversity Center of BASF
description: Homeless Advocacy Project provides legal services to San Franciscans who are homeless or at risk of losing their housing. It prioritizes people with mental health disabilities.
volunteer: Attorneys, legal professionals, social service professionals and legal and social work student interns needed.

description: Homeless Children's Network reduces the trauma of homelessness and domestic violence by providing mental health consultations and treatment. It also operates a resource center that offers training sessions on subjects such as parenting skills.
volunteer: Please call about volunteer opportunities.

description: Homeward Bound of Marin operates the only emergency shelter for homeless families in Marin County, which is the entry point for our Family Services Program.  Homeward Bound of Marin also operates five supportive housing programs for families, including a new site called Oma Village in Novato.
volunteer: Make dinner for clients at a homeless shelter and help with packaging products.

description: La Casa de las Madres provides shelter and support services to individuals who are at risk of or have been exposed to abuse.
volunteer: Supervising children, community outreach and education, crisis line counseling, drop-in center assistance, instructors for various activities (yoga, creative writing, etc.), interpretation, marketing and more.

description: Operating under the umbrella of the Tenderloin Housing Clinic, La Voz Latina is committed to supporting the various needs of low-income, monolingual Spanish-speaking immigrants in the neighborhood by providing housing assistance, immigration information and advocacy, Spanish interpretation, public safety, and leadership and skill development.
volunteer: Macaulay Park event setup and activities, outreach efforts, and clerical duties.

description: Larkin Street Youth Services offers a continuum of services, including outreach and engagement, housing, education and employment, and health and wellness to young people experiencing homelessness between the ages of 12 and 24.
volunteer: Limited long-term and short-term opportunities available.

description: Life House Recovery Homes consists of six sober living homes located throughout Alameda and Contra Costa counties.
volunteer: Spend time with the people in the program.

description: LifeMoves provides interim housing and supportive services for homeless families and individuals to rapidly return to stable housing and achieve long-term self-sufficiency.
volunteer: Work directly with clients and children, help to improve facility spaces for clients or help with advocating and education.

description: Loved Twice distributes baby clothing via social workers who serve families with newborns.
volunteer: Host a baby clothing drive at your office, serve on the board of directors or help raise funds to help infants living in crisis.

organization: Martin de Porres House of Hospitality
description: Martin de Porres House of Hospitality is a free restaurant that serves breakfast and lunch during the week, plus brunch on Sundays.
volunteer: Help in the kitchen any day.

description: Mercy Housing California providers low-income housing programs that target families, seniors and people with special needs.
volunteer: Volunteers are needed during regular business hours to help with landscaping, cleaning, community gardening, teaching classes, tutoring, serving as tech support in computer labs, hosting community meals, holiday parties, birthday parties, and administrative and event support.

description: Monument Crisis Center is a family resource center that serves central and eastern Contra Costa County.
volunteer: Food stocking, reception and client intake.

description: North Beach Citizens is a nonprofit homeless resource center that provides housing referrals.
volunteer: Assist with grants and in-office support.

description: Oakland Elizabeth House is a shelter that serves homeless women and children.
volunteer: Child care, mentoring, tutoring and office support.

description: Open Heart Kitchen serves prepared, nutritious meals free of charge to the hungry people of the Tri-Valley area.
volunteer: Help prepare and serve food.

description: PATH operates services throughout the state of California and connects people to a variety of homeless service programs.
volunteer: Participate in the welcome home program, build hygiene kits for homeless neighbors or help with administrative work.
address: 31 N. Second St, Ste. 265, San Jose

description: PRC helps low income, no income, disabled, and homeless adults in San Francisco overcome health-related challenges to stable housing by addressing substance use, mental illness, HIV/AIDS; linking them to benefit and employment income; building independent living capacity through transitional housing.
volunteer: Fundraising/marketing, board/committee service, administrative projects, employment readiness training and workshop support, and residential building maintenance.

description: PHC connects people experiencing and at-risk of homelessness to services by hosting large-scale events five times a year. Between events, they offer ongoing assistance through their Every Day Connect program. Services include medical, dental and vision care, as well as employment counseling, housing assistance and legal aid.
volunteer: Help facilitate the food bank, cafe and participant check-in and checkout.
address: 25 Van Ness Ave., Ste. 340, San Francisco

description: Project WeHOPE is an emergency and supportive housing shelter for the unhoused, homeless and at-risk adults in East Palo Alto and surrounding San Mateo County and Santa Clara County communities.
volunteer: Help with client dinners, laundry, fundraising events and more.

description: Raphael House provides shelter and long-term assistance for homeless and low-income families.
volunteer: Help in the kitchen, assist with shelter upkeep projects, holiday and special events, tutoring club, children's program, and career development program.

description: Ritter Center provides health and social services to individuals and families in Marin County.
volunteer: Work directly with clients, fundraising opportunities, outreach, graphic design and general administrative tasks.

description: Rubicon offers a number of services, including job training and financial literacy skills.
volunteer: Tax prep workshop (training will be provided).

description: Ruby's Place is a shelter that serves survivors of domestic violence and human trafficking.
volunteer: Assist with weekday children's programs, work on landscaping, painting, room remodels and office duties.

description: SAVE provides shelter, support and educational opportunities to individuals and families.
volunteer: Volunteers must complete 40 hours of training to become a domestic violence advocate. For more information please visit http://save-dv.org/you-can-help/volunteer/.

description: Safe Time Host coordinates housing for college students and others at imminent risk of homelessness through a home-sharing program. A thorough screening process including interviews, references, and background checks assures that guests and hosts are compatible and safe.
volunteer: Become a Safe Time host and provide extra space in your home for one to two months.

description: Samaritan House is the largest truck-to-table food distribution agency in San Mateo County. Other free services include shelter and housing assistance; free medical and dental clinics; free clothing, shoes, backpacks with school supplies for children; personalized case management and much more.
volunteer: Help in the kitchen, pantry, dining room, kids closet, medical and dental clinics or work with clients directly on money management.

description: SF-Marin Food Bank's mission is to end hunger in San Francisco and Marin. From their pantry network and home-delivered groceries, to nutrition-education classes and food-stamp enrollment, they work in many ways to nourish and empower neighbors in need.
volunteer: Help repackage bulk food into family-size quantities, assemble grocery boxes and sort food; drive groceries to homebound seniors on a weekly basis; drive groceries every other week to West Marin; teach cooking classes with the Nutrition Program.
address: 900 Pennsylvania Ave., San Francisco; 75 Digital Dr., Novato

organization: Shelter Inc. of Contra Costa County
description: Shelter Inc. of Contra Costa County provides low-income and homeless families and individuals with housing and resources they need to become self-sufficient.
volunteer: Provide and serve meals at the emergency family shelter in Martinez.

description: Shepherd’s Gate is a Christian nonprofit that offers both short-term and long-term and transitional programs tailored to the individual needs of the woman and child they serve. Programs include job-skills training, financial education, nutrition and health lessons, child care, parenting classes and case management.
volunteer: Year-round volunteers needed in the following areas: child care, administration, events and facility maintenance.

description: Simply the Basics provides basic needs, particularly hygiene products, to the community for improved health and wellness. Additional programs include healthy living classes and in-kind donation support to nonprofit partners. Simply the Basics is the first full-scale hygiene bank in the nation.
volunteer: Volunteer groups of 5 to 15 people sort and pack hygiene items into kits, which are distributed to people in need. Host a drive for unused products, contact Simply the Basics to learn more about their needs.

description: Social Advocates for Youth focuses on Sonoma County’s at-risk youths by offering short-term, emergency shelter and affordable housing as well as mental health counseling and career-readiness programs.
volunteer: Skilled volunteers are needed to help with group service projects and building maintenance.

organization: Society of St. Vincent de Paul of Alameda County
description: Society of St. Vincent de Paul of Alameda County offers shelter, food and support to people in need.
volunteer: Assist in the dining room/kitchen, at the help desk and more.

description: Sonoma County Homeless Action! is a grassroots group that works to protect the human rights of those forced to remain on the streets and to advocate for housing and other immediate solutions.
volunteer: Outreach to homeless people, research, policy development, committee work with others who aren't waiting for someone else to provide the answers.

description: St. Anthony’s Foundation aids individuals and families in poverty to maintain their respect and dignity through many programs, including a food kitchen, addiction services, free clothing program and more.
volunteer: Volunteers assist in the dining room, free clothing program, technology lab, medical clinic, social work center and operations and can serve on the Young Professionals Council.

description: St. Joseph's Family Center operates a large food distribution pantry and hot meal program.
volunteer: Help with pantry operations and hot meal prep and serving.

description: Each year St. Mary's Center helps about 1,000 seniors living alone, operates a winter emergency shelter and a year-round drop-in center for homeless women; helps families who need groceries and operates a preschool for children in poverty.
volunteer: Host and serve a meal for shelter guests or the Sunday dinner program; reception and greeting seniors; preschool.

organization: St. Vincent de Paul Society of San Francisco
description: St. Vincent de Paul Society of San Francisco offers shelter, food and support to people in need.
volunteer: Help at breakfast and dinner shifts, folding clean sheets and linens, computer lab assistance, and the Emergency HotLine (advance training required).
address: St. Boniface Church, 133 Golden Gate Ave.; St. John the Evangelist 1661 15th St.

description: STAND! provides prevention, intervention and treatment programs to stop domestic violence and child abuse.
volunteer: Tutor shelter residents (adult and children), work on the crisis line, support and lead children's activities, fundraise and participate in special events.

description: Sunnyvale Community Services operates a food bank and offers financial assistance for Sunnyvale residents and veterans support services in Santa Clara County.
volunteer: Please call about volunteer opportunities.

description: Swords to Plowshares helps build self-sufficiency to all veterans in need, particularly those who are homeless or living in poverty.
volunteer: Various opportunities available; please contact for details.
address: 1060 Howard St., San Francisco; 2719 Telegraph Ave., Oakland

description: TNDC provides housing and such as the Tenderloin After-School Program and Tenderloin People’s Garden to low-income residents.
volunteer: Office administrative assistance, tutor at the Tenderloin After-School Program, or harvest local produce from the community garden.

description: The Gubbio Project provides resting spots and services for those in need of shelter.
volunteer: Assist unhoused guests during the day as they rest in beds, cook and serve breakfast, eat with guests, and volunteer on their development and events committee.
address: St. Boniface Church, 133 Golden Gate Ave.; St. John the Evangelist 1661 15th St.

description: The Living Room gives women and children a place to rest during the day when shelters are closed.
volunteer: Serve breakfast and/or lunch, sort donations, assist program staff, interact with women and their children, distribute hygiene items and other essentials.

description: Trinity Center serves homeless and working poor adults in Walnut Creek. Services include providing food, breakfast and hot lunch, showers and laundry, clothing, mail and telephone access, referral services, and help with benefit applications.
volunteer: Writing grants, serve on the board, help with new client intake and more.

description: Wardrobe for Opportunity helps low income individuals find a job, keep a job and build a career.
volunteer: Stylists, donation sorters, fundraising committee members, data entry, and build-a-career mentors needed.

description:
Winter Nights Rotating Homeless Family Shelter in Contra Costa County, California provides homeless families with children a clean, safe, and warm shelter with bedding at night and a daytime services center.
Faith congregations provide space, meals, and volunteers on a two-week rotating basis. Professional staff supervise the shelter at all times.
volunteer: Congregation volunteers provide meals, homework help, read with children, go on outings, make crafts, play games or other activities.

description: Youth Spirit Artworks provides a job training program that serves at-risk and homeless youths, ages 16-25.
volunteer: Help with events, special work days, workshop and training facilitation, interested in skilled new board memebers.
